journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of the American Academy of Religion

title-group.article-title: The Postpositivist Choice: Tracy or Lindbeck?

p.mixed-citation: "Those who like brisker language might wish to define this new scene not as one merely of re-evaluation but as the beginning of the 'disintegration of secular culture'--but that judgment is probably quite premature." (1981: 31)31 Those who like brisker language might wish to define this new scene not as one merely of re-evaluation but as the beginning of the 'disintegration of secular culture'--but that judgment is probably quite premature 1981

George Lindbeck, The Nature of Doc- trine: Religion and Theology in a Postliberal Age
Lindbeck
The Nature of Doctrine: Religion and Theology in a Postliberal Age
The Superiority of Pre-Critical ExegesisThe Superiority of Pre-Critical Exegesis

David Tracy writes, "What remains constant in the shift from modernity to post-modernity is the fact that such contemporary critiques of modernity deepen the fundamental commitment to those purely secular standards for knowledge and action initiated by the Enlighten- ment. (1978: 8)
Tracy
8 What remains constant in the shift from modernity to post-modernity is the fact that such contemporary critiques of modernity deepen the fundamental commitment to those purely secular standards for knowledge and action initiated by the Enlightenment 1978

James Turner remarks, "Despite the perils supposed to beset belief [in God], unbelief in fact remained unthinkable to all but a tiny handful [in the 18th century]" (35)
Turner
35 Despite the perils supposed to beset belief [in God], unbelief in fact remained unthinkable to all but a tiny handful [in the 18th century]
the myth of the givenThe myth of the given

Frei, "As the reader sympathetically follows the progres- sive unfolding of Jesus identity in the narrative she must simultaneously be 'affirming' and 'adoring' him in the present. If not, the reader has missed the story's meaning because she has not correctly identified its major character. Frei's actual reading shows that in the case of at least this one realistic narrative, meaning is unintelligible apart from reader response" (126)
Frei
126 As the reader sympathetically follows the progressive unfolding of Jesus identity in the narrative she must simultaneously be 'affirming' and 'adoring' him in the present. If not, the reader has missed the story's meaning because she has not correctly identified its major character. Frei's actual reading shows that in the case of at least this one realistic narrative, meaning is unintelligible apart from reader response
